Ayuthaya, Lord Chamberlain of the Royal Family and Household of Thailand ** Other officials of the BRH * 2nd Massed military bands of the 1st Division, King's Guard, First Army, RTA * Representatives of schools and business establishments with royal patronage and of the late King's royal projects * 2nd Guards Regiment ** 2nd Battalion, 1st Infantry Regiment, King's Own Bodyguard ** 5th Battalion, 11th Infantry Regiment, King's Guard == Mourning == [[File:Mourning Points for King Bhumibol Adulyadej at Sanam Luang.jpg|thumb|300px|King's portrait displayed at [[Sanam Luang]] for public mourning]] [[File:Queue for pay respecting to King Bhumibol Adulyadej's body - 2016-12-06 (3).jpg|thumb|300px|Thai people wait to pay homage to the King's body which lay in state at Phra Thinang Dusit Maha Prasat.]] [[File:Half mast Bangkok School 2016.jpg|thumb|300px|Thai national flag flown at half mast at Assumption College Bangkok during the mourning of the King Bhumibol]] The government declared a year-long mourning period for Bhumibol. Citizens were asked to refrain from participating in "joyful events" and entertainment for 30 days following his death; as a result, a number of events, including sports (such as the [[2016 Thai League|Thai League football season]], which ended entirely),{{cite web|title=Kirins bag title as league ties are cancelled|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/sports/1110897/kirins-bag-title-as-league-ties-are-cancelled|work=Bangkok Post|accessdate=15 October 2016}} were cancelled or postponed. Entertainment outlets such as cinemas, nightclubs and theatres announced that they would shut down or operate under reduced hours during this period.{{cite web|title=WHAT'S CANCELED, CLOSED AND OPEN IN BANGKOK DURING MOURNING PERIOD|url=http://www.khaosodenglish.com/life/arts/2016/10/14/whats-canceled-closed-open-bangkok-mourning-period/|work=Khaosod English|accessdate=15 October 2016}}{{cite web|title=Drinking, Partying Off Limits in Thailand as Death of King Hits Tourism|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-10-14/king-s-death-sees-airlines-tour-agents-brace-for-thai-slowdown|work=Bloomberg|accessdate=15 October 2016}}{{cite web|title=Thai king death: Thousands mourn at royal palace|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-37654314|work=BBC News|accessdate=15 October 2016}} The mourning period prompted concerns from Thailand's tourism industry, which felt that the mood of the country, as well as the cancelled events, would reduce interest in visiting Thailand. Upon the announcement of his death, all television channels suspended regular programming and simulcast special programmes from the [[television pool of Thailand]], which consisted of monochrome videos and photos of Bhumibol, and coverage of royal events. International channels were also blacked out and replaced by this programming. Following the funeral procession on 14 October 2016, the channels continued to air the pooled tribute content until midnight local time, after which they were allowed to resume regular programming. However, for the remainder of the 30-day mourning period, all broadcasters were forbidden from broadcasting programmes that featured "any element of entertainment, dancing, joy, violence, impoliteness or overly expressed emotion", nor any [[Lèse majesté in Thailand|non-official information, speculation or criticism]] related to the deceased King and [[Vajiralongkorn|his successor]]. Most Thai media outlets and websites switched to greyscale colour schemes as well.{{cite web|title=All TV channels carry monochrome broadcasts|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/general/1109869/all-tv-channels-carry-monochrome-broadcasts|work=Bangkok Post|accessdate=15 October 2016}}{{cite web|title=TV, radio programmes to resume, with restrictions|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/general/1110680/tv-radio-programmes-to-resume-with-restrictions|work=Bangkok Post|accessdate=15 October 2016}} After a brief return to monochrome for the King's 1st death anniversary on 13 October 2017, colour television broadcasts, with the same restrictions are before, resumed on 19 October the same year.{{cite web|url=https://www.bangkokpost.com/news/general/1346031/tv-returns-to-full-colour-to-present-funerals|title=TV returns to full colour to present funeral|work=Bangkok Post|accessdate=20 October 2017}} Out of respect for the mourning, many Thai malls, including all [[Central Pattana]] and [[The Mall Group]] properties, chose not to install extensive [[Christmas]] displays and decorations for the holiday season. Some installed memorials to Bhumibol instead.{{cite web|url=http://www.khaosodenglish.com/news/business/2016/11/26/not-beginning-look-lot-like-christmas/|title=It’s (Not) Beginning To Look a Lot Like Christmas|date=26 November 2016|publisher=|accessdate=1 October 2017}} ==Aftermath== Since the death of the king, ultra-royalists in Thailand have criticized and harassed those who did not wear mourning black.{{cite web | url = http://www.khaosodenglish.com/politics/2016/10/16/ultra-royalists-guilt-shame-people-dont-wear-mourning-black/ | title = Ultra-Royalists Guilt-Shame People Who Don’t Wear Mourning Black | publisher = Khaosod English | website = [[Khaosod]] | author-first = Teeranai | author-last = Charuvastra | date = 16 October 2016 | accessdate = 16 October 2016 }} They also subjected to [[witch-hunt]]s people whom they accused of disrespecting the deceased monarch. On 14 October 2016, angry ultra-royalist groups in [[Phuket Province]] thronged the residence of a man who posted on social media a number of comments which they thought offensive to the late king and violated the [[Lèse majesté in Thailand|''lèse-majesté'' law]], despite the local police having declared that the comments were not in breach of the law. The groups dispersed after the police agreed to prosecute the man for the crime of ''lèse-majesté''.{{cite web | location = Bangkok | publisher = Matichon | date = 15 October 2016 | accessdate = 15 October 2016 | url = http://www.prachachat.net/news_detail.php?newsid=1476504517 | script-title = ชาวภูเก็ตฮือล้อมบ้านลูกชายร้านเต้าหู้กลางดึกอ้างโพสต์ FB จาบจ้วง แจ้งความ ม. 112 แล้ว | title = Chāo phūket hư̄ lǭm bān lūkchāi rān khāi taohū klāng dưk ‘āng phōs ‘ēfbī čhāpčhūang čhǣngkhwām mǭ nưng nưng sǭng lǣo | language = th | website = Prachachat }}{{cite web | url = http://bangkok.coconuts.co/2016/10/15/phuket-man-accused-lese-majeste-his-shop-mobbed-over-social-media-post | location = Bangkok | publisher = Coconuts BKK | date = 15 October 2016 | accessdate = 15 October 2016 | title = Phuket man accused of lese majeste, his shop mobbed over social media post }} Similar incidents happened on the following day in [[Phang Nga Province]]. In November 2016, [[Nangrong School]] in [[Buriram Province]] seized colourful winter jackets from students and required them to wear those in mourning colours only. The students were reportedly distressed to lose their jackets due to the cold weather, and many did not own multiple warm articles of clothing.{{cite web|author-last=Thaitrakulpanich|author-first=Asaree|date=3 November 2016|accessdate=4 November 2016|title=Buriram school seizes students' colorful winter jackets|website=Khao Sod English|location=Bangkok|publisher=[[Khao Sod]]|url=http://www.khaosodenglish.com/news/2016/11/03/buriram-school-seizes-students-colorful-winter-jackets/}} On 28 November, the director of a public school in [[Ranong Province]] was removed from office for not wearing mourning black on her first day at work.{{cite web|url=http://bangkok.coconuts.co/2016/11/29/new-public-school-director-removed-post-wearing-red-dress|title=New public school director removed from post for wearing red dress|date=2016-11-29|accessdate=2016-11-29|publisher=Coconuts Bangkok|website=Coconuts|location=Bangkok}} The [[National Council for Peace and Order]], the junta ruling Thailand, also announced after the death of Bhumibol that it will hunt down ''lèse-majesté'' fugitives.{{cite web | url = http://www.nationmultimedia.com/news/kingdomgrieves/30298400 | author-first = Wasamon | author-last = Audjarint | website = [[The Nation (Thailand)|The Nation]] | publisher = Nation Multimedia | location = Bangkok | date = 26 October 2016 | accessdate = 26 October 2016 | title = Hunt for lese majeste fugitives }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite web|author-link=Jonathan Head|author-first=Jonathan|author-last=Head|date=16 October 2016|accessdate=16 October 2016|website=[[BBC]]|title=Thai king's death: Who holds power now?|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-37672088?ocid=socialflow_facebook}} * {{cite web|url=https://www.death-notices.co.uk/obituaries-celebrities-death/135/Thailand-King-Bhumibol-S-Death-After-70-Years-Of-Reign|title=Thailand King Bhumibol's death , after 70 years of reign|website=Death-notices.co.uk|publisher=Interpress|location=London|date=17 October 2016|accessdate=17 October 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161019023826/https://www.death-notices.co.uk/obituaries-celebrities-death/135/Thailand-King-Bhumibol-S-Death-After-70-Years-Of-Reign|archivedate=19 October 2016|df=dmy-all}} * {{cite book|author1=The Committee on Public Relations for the Royal Cremation of His Majesty King Bhumibol Adulyadej|title=Media Guide: Royal Cremation of His Majesty King Bhumibol Adulyadej 25–29 October 2017|date=2017|url=https://drive.google.com/file/d/0Bz2OcyfqqEwpZElfSTJabUxGcnc/view?usp=sharing}} {{commonscat|Death of Bhumibol Adulyadej}} {{Bhumibol Adulyadej}} revision.text:
The '''Death of Liliana Barbarita Cepeda''' was a child's death that caused commotion in [[Puerto Rico]] during 1997.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1998-11-23/news/9811220550_1_barbarita-puerto-rico-toledo|title=Case Of Girl's Death Takes Another Twist|publisher=|accessdate=12 August 2017}}</ref> Investigations into the case caused confusion among the general public, because at first it had been claimed by Puerto Rican police that Cepeda had been raped and murdered, then it was alleged that she died accidentally.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1997-06-23/news/9706230080_1_toledo-girl-killer|title=Amid Uproar In Puerto Rico, Police Say Girl Not Murdered|publisher=|accessdate=12 August 2017}}</ref>
==Liliana Barbarita Cepeda== {{Spanish name|Cepeda|Casado}} '''Liliana Barbara "Barbarita" Cepeda Casado''' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.puertadetierra.info/noticias/1997.htm|title=Noticias Puerta de Tierra 1997|website=www.puertadetierra.info|accessdate=12 August 2017}}</ref>(1990–1997) was a young Puerto Rican girl of African descent.
On April 30, 2013, she was, along with [[Lorenzo Gonzalez Cacho]] and several other children who have disappeared or died violent deaths in Puerto Rico, remembered at Puerto Rico's Capitol, during a ceremony to promote reduction of mistreatment of minors in Puerto Rico.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/noticias/locales/nota/reclamanelcesedelmaltratoinfantil-1501513/|title=Reclaman el cese del maltrato infantil|website=El Nuevo Dia|accessdate=12 August 2017}}</ref>
==Case== Liliana Barbarita Cepeda Casado was with her family enjoying a day at the beach swimming on June 8, 1997, when she first disappeared at [[Escambron Beach]] in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]]. People began looking for her all over the beach and under water.
Her body was found on June 9, in the basement of an abandoned building that hosted what was once an Olympic-sized swimming pool used for the [[1979 Pan American Games]] water competitions.
Initially it was said that she had been raped, beaten and murdered. Days after that announcement, however, police recanted, declaring her death as an accidental one. During a press conference, Police chief [[Pedro Toledo]] discussed that her 11 year old brother allegedly admitted that she had fallen to her death as she was playing with him and that, afraid of the consequences this could bring him, her brother claimed she was kidnapped. Toledo later held another press conference, where he admitted his comments could have been misleading. "At that time, I understood that we had to put an end to the hysteria (surrounding the case)" Toledo told the press that day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1997/Girl-s-death-has-enraged-mystified-captivated-public-in-Puerto-Rico/id-11f1f432abeb92d0750bf44169b68ef4|title=Girl's death has enraged, mystified, captivated public in Puerto Rico|website=www.apnewsarchive.com|accessdate=12 August 2017}}</ref>
On November 16, 1998, Jose Luis Ortiz Vega, Barbarita's stepfather<ref>http://www.adendi.com/archivo.asp?num=379921&year=1999&month=1&keyword=</ref> and Eugenio J. Rodriguez Galindo were arrested and charged with the kidnapping and murder of Cepeda Casado. During a preliminary court hearing on December 16 of that year, it was determined there was probable cause to accuse the two of first degree murder and of kidnapping, in addition to gun law violations. A third man, named Eliezer Santana Baez, testified he had witnessed some of what the other two men had been accused of doing. Santana Baez, however, had also declared that he was not there when Cepeda Casado died and that he had been coerced to lie by authorities.
It was later argued by the two accused men's defense that some of the evidence offered by prosecution had been in the hands of the public ministry and that they had not been handed to defense until the day of a hearing, 15 January 1999, and as such, the accusations should be discarded. These motions were later dismissed by jury.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lexjuris.com/LEXJURIS/Dts99/LEX99150.htm|title=LEX90000|website=www.lexjuris.com|accessdate=12 August 2017}}</ref>
Six months after being jailed in 1998, both Ortiz Vega and Rodriguez Galindo had to be released due to being jailed without a trial.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adendi.com/archivo.asp?num=382973&year=1999&month=5&keyword=|title=ADENDI|website=www.adendi.com|accessdate=12 August 2017}}</ref>
Santana Baez later alleged that he had lied about the case<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adendi.com/archivo.asp?num=637538&year=2004&month=10&keyword=|title=ADENDI|website=www.adendi.com|accessdate=12 August 2017}}</ref> and a judge then found no cause against Rodriguez Galindo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.puertorico-herald.org/issues/2001/vol5n02/Year2000-en.html|title=PUERTO RICO HERALD: THE YEAR 2000 AT A GLANCE|website=www.puertorico-herald.org|accessdate=12 August 2017}}</ref> Santana Baez was later found guilty of the murder of a Puerto Rican dancer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://corp.primerahora.com/archivo.asp?guid=A174AD8172EC4303ABF5A53928534436&year=2004&keyword=|title=Archivo Digital de PrimeraHora.com|website=corp.primerahora.com|accessdate=12 August 2017}}</ref>
Ortiz Vega died of [[Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome|AIDS]].
