It was ultimately passed by the House and Senate, but President Obama refused to sign it into law.{{cite web|title=The Conscience Protection Act of 2016|url=https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/114/s304|website=Govtrack.us|accessdate=May 31, 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Messer|first1=Luke|title=House Amendment to S. 304, Conscience Protection Act of 2016|url=https://policy.house.gov/legislative/bills/house-amendment-s-304-conscience-protection-act-2016|website=RPC|accessdate=June 1, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Eaton|first1=Sabrina|title=House passes 'Conscience Protection Act' to oppose abortion|url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2016/07/house_passes_conscience_protec.html |accessdate=June 1, 2017|date=July 13, 2016}} ====The Abortion Non-Discrimination Act (ANDA)==== By federal law, federal funding is required to be withheld from states who do not enforce the Weldon Amendment that prevents discrimination against healthcare providers if they refuse to provide abortion services.{{cite web|url=https://www.hhs.gov/civil-rights/for-individuals/conscience-protections/factsheet/index.html|website=HHS.GOV |title=Overview of Federal Statutory Health Care Provider Conscience Protections |accessdate=June 8, 2017}} In 2014, California began enforcing a 1975 state law requiring all insurance companies to charge and cover all [[subscribers]] for abortion services, even if they object based on [[religious]] or [[conscience]] beliefs. [[President Obama]] refused to enforce the federal statute against this, violating the Weldon Amendment in the opinion of Fleming and many others.{{cite news|last1=Sullivan|first1=Peter|title=Republicans accuse Obama of failing to enforce abortion law|url=http://thehill.com/policy/healthcare/267396-republicans-accuse-obama-of-failing-to-enforce-abortion-law|accessdate=June 1, 2017|date=January 29, 2016}}{{cite news|title=Kaiser Health News|url=http://khn.org/morning-breakout/california-abortion-coverage/|accessdate=June 1, 2017|date=August 25, 2014}} Fleming introduced legislation to provide health insurance subscribers a choice to purchase plans that do not cover abortions.{{cite news|last1=Gehrke|first1=Joel|title=GOP Rep: Leadership Blocked Bill Protecting Churches from Funding Abortion |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/394360/gop-rep-leadership-blocked-bill-protecting-churches-funding-abortion-joel-gehrke|accessdate=June 1, 2017|publisher=National Review |date=December 10, 2014}} ====Seniors' Tax Simplification Act of 2015==== With each congressional session, Fleming introduced this bill designed to improve convenience and lower tax-filing costs to seniors. Though a senior's income may be limited to only [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]] benefits, the [[IRS]] requires all [[senior citizens]] to use the long [[form 1040]] to file taxes. This act was designed to reduce the senior taxpayer filing to one simple page saving time, complexity and cost.{{cite web|title=H.R.1397 - Seniors' Tax Simplification Act of 2015|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/114th-congress/house-bill/1397|website=Congress.gov|accessdate=June 1, 2017}}{{cite web|title=ATR Supports Tax Simplification for Seniors|url=https://www.atr.org/atr-supports-tax-simplification-seniors|website=Americans for Tax Reform|accessdate=June 1, 2017}} ====H. Res. 615 of 2009==== During the debate over healthcare reform in Congress in 2009, Congressman Fleming recognized that members of Congress were likely to be exempted from the mandates and higher premiums expected from the [[Affordable Care Act]], also known as [[Obamacare]].{{cite news|title=Overwhelming Evidence That Obamacare Caused Premiums To Increase Substantially|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/theapothecary/2016/07/28/overwhelming-evidence-that-obamacare-caused-premiums-to-increase-substantially/#5bc6d0ab15be|accessdate=June 2, 2017|date=July 28, 2016}} On July 13, 2009, he introduced H. Res. 615, "expressing the sense of the House of Representatives that members who vote in favor of the establishment of a public, federal government-run health insurance option are urged to forgo their right to participate in the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program (FEHBP) and agree to enroll under that public option."{{cite web|title=H.Res.615|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/111th-congress/house-resolution/615|website=Congress.gov|accessdate=June 2, 2017}} The resolution created a public outcry, after an interview of Fleming by Fox News' Meghan Kelly, demanding that members of Congress should also be subject to [[Obamacare]]. Consequently, language was placed in the [[Affordable Care Act]] requiring members of Congress and their staff to leave the more affordable [[Federal Employees Health Benefits Program]] with much lower premiums and deductibles, and obtain healthcare insurance through the [[DC Health Link|DC Exchange]], a product of the [[Affordable Care Act]].{{cite news|title=What Happens To A Congressman's Health Insurance If Obamacare Goes Down?|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/12/523335954/what-happens-to-a-congressmans-health-insurance-if-obamacare-goes-down|accessdate=June 2, 2017|agency=NPR}}{{cite news |last1=Livingston |first1=Shelby|title=Insurance premiums have doubled since 2013, but policies are more generous |url=http://www.modernhealthcare.com/article/20170524/NEWS/170529951|accessdate=June 2, 2017 |date=May 24, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Kelly|first1=Meghan|title=Congressman Fleming Discusses H Res 615 with Meghan Kelly on Fox News|agency=Fox News|date=July 16, 2009}} ====American Health Care Reform Act of 2013==== The [[Affordable Care Act]] ([[Obamacare]]) was signed into law in 2010. Dr. Fleming was vociferously opposed to, and voted against the health care law. He and his House Republican colleagues voted at full strength over fifty times to repeal the unpopular{{cite news|title=More Americans Disapprove Than Approve of Health Care Law|url=http://www.people-press.org/2016/04/27/more-americans-disapprove-than-approve-of-health-care-law/|accessdate=June 1, 2017|date=April 27, 2017}} law prior to 2017.{{cite news|last1=Berenson |first1=Tessa|title=Reminder: The House Voted to Repeal Obamacare More Than 50 Times prior to 2017.|url=http://time.com/4712725/ahca-house-repeal-votes-obamacare/|accessdate=June 1, 2017|date=March 24, 2017}} Citing the over eighteen new taxes, mandates on employers and individuals, and the newly mandated set of [[essential health benefits]]; Fleming emphasized how [[Obamacare]] would damage the economy and reduce access to affordable healthcare for many and fail to provide promised coverage for more Americans.{{cite web|title=Full List of Obamacare Tax Hikes|url=https://www.atr.org/grover-norquist-educates-science-guy-bill-nye-about-real-costs-paris-climate-deal|website=ATR|accessdate=June 2, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1310/27/sotu.01.html|website=cnn.com |title=State of the Union with Candy Crowley |accessdate=June 9, 2017}} He also called [[Obamacare]] "the most dangerous piece of legislation ever passed by Congress." When asked about fixing the healthcare law instead of repealing it, he said it was "not fixable or repairable."Bruce Alpert, [http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2013/10/rep_fleming_gets_attention_for.html Rep. Fleming gets attention for calling Obamacare 'most dangerous law ever passed by Congress'], ''[[The Times-Picayune]]'' (October 28, 2013). He believed, instead, in a market-based healthcare system through which competition can reduce costs and waste, and improve quality and effectiveness of the nation's healthcare system.{{cite news|url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/daily/republican-alternative-to-obamacare-relies-on-repeal-20130922|title=Republican Alternative to Obamacare Relies on Repeal|work=National Journal|date=September 22, 2013 |accessdate=November 20, 2013}}{{cite news|last1=Donachie|first1=Robert|title=Ezekiel Emanuel: Obamacare 'Absolutely' Needs To Be Fixed|url=http://dailycaller.com/2017/06/05/ezekiel-emanuel-obamacare-absolutely-needs-to-be-fixed-watch/|accessdate=June 6, 2017|agency=The Daily Caller|date=June 5, 2017}} In September 2013, Congressman Fleming helped write, cosponsored and introduced the [[Republican Study Committee]]'s [[American Health Care Reform Act of 2013]] and again in 2015, which would repeal the soon-to-be-implemented [[Affordable Care Act]]. Instead of raising taxes, adding mandates and creating massive amounts of regulations to the healthcare system, the [[American Health Care Reform Act of 2013]] was designed to increase competition among providers by taking down state line barriers for health insurance, creating price transparency, tax equity between individual and employer plans, and liberalizing [[health savings account]]s. It would create large [[purchasing cooperative|buying co-ops]] for small businesses, and form strong [[risk pool|high risk pools]] among other mechanisms to deal with [[Pre-existing condition|pre-existing illness]].{{cite web|title=H.R.3121 - American Health Care Reform Act of 2013|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/house-bill/3121|website=Congress.gov|accessdate=June 1, 2017}} The [[Affordable Care Act|ACA]] sharply restricted the use of [[health savings account]]s, though they had been popular since their inception in 2003.{{cite news|last1=Ramthun|first1=Roy|title=Why Is Obamacare Regulating Health Savings Accounts Out of Existence? |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/433639/health-savings-accounts-obamacare-affordable-care-act-killing-hsa|accessdate=June 2, 2017|date=April 5, 2016}}{{cite web|title=History of Health Savings Accounts (HSAs)|url=http://www.afcm.org/hsahistory.html|website=Americans for Free Choice in Medicine|accessdate=June 1, 2017}} In 2013, Congressman Fleming introduced Helping Save Americans' Health Care Choices Act, an expansion of [[health savings account]]s in healthcare policy. [[Health savings account]]s function to allow pre-taxed savings to be used to bridge the cost of deductible and co-payment gaps in healthcare purchasing.{{cite web|title=What is an HSA |url=http://www.hsacenter.com/what-is-an-hsa/|website=hsacenter.com|accessdate=June 1, 2017}} Much of it was incorporated into the [[American Health Care Reform Act of 2013]]. It was introduced again in 2015 by the title of HSA Health Care Choices Act of 2015.{{cite web|title=Helping Save Americans' Health Care Choices Act of 2015|url=https://projects.propublica.org/represent/bills/114/hr3006|website=ProPublica |accessdate=June 1, 2017}} ==== Tax cuts and increases ==== The [[Bush tax cuts]] enacted in 2001 and 2003 could not be made permanent because they were passed under [[Reconciliation (United States Congress)|Budget Reconciliation]]. They expired in 2010 but were renewed temporarily for two years through the bipartisan compromise [[Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization, and Job Creation Act of 2010]]. This led to the eventual passage of the [[American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012|President Obama's Proposed Plan to Increase Taxes]] which kept taxes low on lower income earners but raised taxes above the [[Bush Tax Cuts]] rate on [[small businesses]] and higher earners. Congressman Fleming was outspoken on the subject supporting tax cuts for all Americans. He agreed with many economists who said tax increases would damage the economy and jobs, and that federal taxes and spending should be cut to achieve a faster American [[economic growth]] rate.{{cite web|title=Effects of Income Tax Changes on Economic Growth MORE|url=https://www.brookings.edu/research/effects-of-income-tax-changes-on-economic-growth/|website=Brookings.edu|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}{{cite web|title=Club for Growth PAC Congratulates Rep. John Fleming for Winning Tonight's Louisiana Senate Debate|url=http://www.clubforgrowth.org/election-news/club-for-growth-pac-congratulates-rep-john-fleming-for-winning-tonights-louisiana-senate-debate/|accessdate=June 6, 2017}} In a September 19, 2011, interview on [[MSNBC]] in which Fleming was critical of President Obama's proposed plan to increase taxes, he was questioned about the reported $6.3 million of gross [[revenues]] his private restaurant company received the previous year. Fleming responded to host [[Chris Jansing]] by saying, "that's before you pay 500 employees, you pay rent, you pay equipment, and food" [[Overhead (business)|(business overhead)]]; "the actual net income was a mere fraction of that...It is more like $600,000 of that $6.3 million...So by the time I feed my family I have, maybe $400,000 left over to invest in new locations, upgrade my locations, buy more equipment."{{cite news|last1=Seitz-Wald|first1=Alex|title=Multi-Millionaire Rep. Says He Can't Afford A Tax Hike Because He Only Has $400K A Year After Feeding Family|url=https://thinkprogress.org/multi-millionaire-rep-says-he-cant-afford-a-tax-hike-because-he-only-has-400k-a-year-after-feeding-68990814b15f|accessdate=May 29, 2017 |date=September 19, 2011}} When Jansing asked Fleming if he thought the "average person" might be unsympathetic to Fleming's position, Fleming responded, "Class warfare never created a job...This is not about attacking people who make certain incomes. You know in this country, most people feel that being successful in their business is a virtue, not a vice, and once we begin to identify it as a vice, this country is going down."Alpert, Bruce. [http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2011/09/rep_john_fleming_of_louisiana.html "Rep. John Fleming of Louisiana catches flak for income remarks."] ''The Times-Picayune'', September 20, 2011. Fleming's remarks were widely reported and resulted in considerable commentary. Bruce Alpert, of Louisiana newspaper ''[[The Times-Picayune]],'' reported that "on liberal blogs, Fleming was portrayed as insensitive to millions of working Americans who are struggling to meet expenses in the face of high unemployment and stagnant wages." Conservative sources including [[Bill O'Reilly (political commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]] and the [[Drudge Report]] defended Fleming's remarks. Josh Beavers, publisher of the ''[[Minden Press-Herald]]'' in Fleming's hometown, wrote an editorial which stated, "[Fleming's] sentiment was only that the more taxes he pays the fewer people he can employ. High taxes on business owners thwart economic activity."''The O'Reilly Factor''. Fox News. September 22, 2011. [http://www.foxnews.com/on-air/oreilly/2011/09/23/bill-oreilly-hits-back-jon-stewart#ixzz1Z5bGvPQJ Transcript.]Beavers, Josh. [http://www.press-herald.com/index.php/opinion/josh-beavers/1323-congressman-fleming-said-nothing-wrong "Congressman Fleming Said Nothing Wrong."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402130122/http://www.press-herald.com/index.php/opinion/josh-beavers/1323-congressman-fleming-said-nothing-wrong |date=April 2, 2012 }} ''Minden Press-Herald'', September 21, 2011. ===Activities in Congress led by Fleming=== ====Co-founder of the [[Freedom Caucus|House Freedom Caucus]]==== Fleming, and his fellow [[congressional]] Republicans, began the [[111th Congress]] in 2009 with Democrats attaining a [[supermajority]] in the [[United States House of Representatives|House]] and [[United States Senate|Senate]], and the [[President of the United States|Presidency]]. In reaction to a series of [[Progressivism|progressive]] bills enacted into law including the [[American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009|Stimulus bill]], the [[Affordable Care Act]], and the [[Dodd-Frank Act]]; [[Conservatism|conservatives]] across America created a number of local activist groups, collectively called the [[Tea Party Movement]]. Republicans in the House and their supporters became determined to regain the House to stop the sudden progressive shift in federal government policy. Republican House members, led by then [[House Minority Leader]] [[John Boehner]], created the [[Pledge to America]] that outlined a [[Party platform|platform]] to reverse the growth in government spending as well as to repeal the Affordable Care Act, the Dodd-Frank Act and other items. During the 2010 elections, many House Republican candidates ran on the [[Pledge to America]] platform with enthusiastic support from the [[Tea Party Movement]]. The 2010 election year ended with Republicans taking the majority by winning 63 seats from Democrats.{{cite news|last1=Peoples|first1=Steve|title=Final House Race Decided; GOP Net Gain: 63 Seats|url=http://www.rollcall.com/news/-201279-1.html|accessdate=June 8, 2017 |agency=Roll Call|date=December 8, 2010}}{{cite news|last1=Cohen|first1=Tom|title=5 years later, here's how the tea party changed politics |url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/02/27/politics/tea-party-greatest-hits/|accessdate=June 8, 2017|agency=CNN Politics|date=February 28, 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Ray|first1=Michael|title=Tea Party movement|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Tea-Party-movement|website=Encyclopaedia Britannica|accessdate=June 8, 2017}} The high expectations of conservative constituents of Republican House members, generally, and Speaker [[John Boehner]], particularly; led to conflict and division among House members. A number of conservative members from within the House [[Republican Study Committee]], began to resist initiatives led by Speaker Boehner when he appeared to be overly cooperative (in the view of conservatives) with House Democrats and [[President Obama]] on issues like taxes, the [[Affordable Care Act]] and [[illegal immigration]] and appeared to be not committed to the [[Pledge to America]]. When Speaker Boehner was reluctantly forced by conservative members to lead a [[United States federal government shutdown of 2013|shutdown]] of the federal government over the implementation and funding of the [[Affordable Care Act]], [[John Boehner]] began to retaliate against individual Republican members who were critical of Boehner and the rest of the House leadership for not adequately (in the view of conservatives) resisting the progressive policies of [[President Obama]] and congressional Democrats. Retaliations ranged from removing House members from [[congressional committees]] and positions of committee leadership, to supporting Republican primary candidates to oppose them. Also, the [[Republican Study Committee]], through its open policy to all Republican members (growing to over 170 members), transitioned from a smaller conservative group to one that aligned itself with the more [[The Establishment|establishment]]-oriented policies of Speaker Boehner.{{cite news|last1=Buck|first1=Ken|title=Freedom Caucus member reveals GOP's 'vindictive retaliation'|url=https://nypost.com/2017/04/08/freedom-caucus-member-exposes-gops-vindictive-retaliation/|accessdate=June 8, 2017|agency=New York Post|date=April 8, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Wong|first1=Scott|title=Boehner defends retaliation against unruly Republican members|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/245958-boehner-defends-retaliation-against-unruly-members|accessdate=June 8, 2017|agency=The Hill|date=June 15, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Martosko|first1=David|title=The speaker's revenge: John Boehner punishes conservative Republicans who 'p***ed him off' by trying to oust him by removing high-profile committee posts |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2899963/Welcome-new-USSR-Conservative-Republicans-lose-committee-assignments-retaliation-voting-against-Speaker-John-Boehner-contentious-leadership-election.html |accessdate=June 8, 2017 |agency=Daily Mail |date=January 6, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=French|first1=Lauren|title=Conservatives split off from Republican Study Committee|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/01/conservatives-split-off-from-republican-study-committee-114222|accessdate=June 8, 2017|agency=Politico|date=January 13, 2015}} In January 2015, feeling that the [[Republican Study Committee]] had become too [[The Establishment|establishment]]-aligned and insufficiently conservative, and citing Speaker Boehner's continued political battle against conservative members; nine House members came together in a series of meetings to consider and ultimately create a more nimble, consistently conservative group consisting of approximately 40 conservative House members. They formed an official congressional caucus and named it the [[Freedom Caucus|House Freedom Caucus]]. Congressman Fleming of Louisiana was among the nine founding members.{{cite news|last1=French|first1=Lauren|title=9 Republicans launch House Freedom Caucus|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/01/house-freedom-caucus-conservative-legislation-114593|accessdate=June 8, 2017|agency=Politico|date=January 26, 2015}} Once fully organized, the [[Freedom Caucus|House Freedom Caucus]] began to oppose Boehner policies leading to continued divisions and conflicts within the [[Republican Conference of the United States House of Representatives|Republican House Conference]]. In July 2015, Freedom Caucus member, [[Mark Meadows (North Carolina politician)|Mark Meadows]] of [[North Carolina]], without warning; submitted a written [[motion to vacate]] the chair (of the [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House]]). Though rarely done, it is a [[privileged motion]] meaning that any member can submit and trigger a series of [[parliamentary procedure]]s culminating in a new vote for Speaker of the House.{{cite news|last1=Bialik|first1=Carl|title=The Hard-Line Republicans Who Pushed John Boehner Out|url=https://fivethirtyeight.com/datalab/the-hard-line-republicans-who-pushed-john-boehner-out/|accessdate=June 8, 2017|agency=FiveThirtyEight|date=September 25, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Dickinson|first1=Tim|title=Meet the Right-Wing Rebels Who Overthrew John Boehner|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/news/meet-the-right-wing-rebels-who-overthrew-john-boehner-20151006|accessdate=June 8, 2017|agency=The Rolling Stone|date=October 6, 2015}} The motion accelerated the pressure on Boehner, whose popularity had declined considerably, nationally and among House Republicans in general. Spurred by the timing of the visit to the Capitol by [[Pope Francis]]; Speaker Boehner, a devout Catholic, announced his resignation as Speaker and as a member of Congress on September 25, 2017.{{cite news |last1=Raju |first1=Manu |title=Why John Boehner quit |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/09/25/politics/why-john-boehner-quit/index.html|accessdate=June 8, 2017|agency=CNN Politics|date=September 26, 2015}} Fleming, in addition to being among the nine founding members of the House Freedom Caucus, also served on the first Freedom Caucus [[board of directors]] and led the effort to impeach the Commissioner of the IRS.{{cite news|last1=McPherson|first1=Lindsey|title=House Freedom Caucus Elects Board Members, Meadows to Run for Chairman |url=http://www.rollcall.com/news/politics/house-freedom-caucus-member |agency=Roll Call |date=November 29, 2016 |accessdate=June 8, 2017}} ====Attempt to impeach the [[Commissioner of Internal Revenue|Commissioner of the IRS]]==== Soon after the [[Tea Party Movement]] began in 2009, local and national Tea Party organizations began to complain that the [[Internal Revenue Service|IRS]] would not approve their applications for [[Tax exemption|tax exempt status]], a certification necessary for the [[wikt:viability|viability]] of [[nonprofit organization]]s. In 2013, [[Lois Lerner]], a high level IRS employee, disclosed as Director of Rulings and Agreements in the Exempt Organizations, that the [[conservatism|conservative]] Tea Party organizations were targeted by the IRS to be denied tax exempt status while [[liberalism|liberal]] groups were given the appropriate certifications. This created the appearance that Lerner was using her power in the IRS for political and ideological benefit. Because of the [[IRS targeting controversy]], Lerner was forced to retire and [[John Koskinen]] was appointed to replace the acting Commissioner to restore integrity of the IRS.{{cite news|title=Rep. Fleming: Impeach the IRS commissioner|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/opinion/2016/09/14/impeach-irs-commissioner-john-koskinen-john-fleming-editorials-debates/90333680/|accessdate=June 10, 2017|agency=USA Today|date=September 14, 2016}} Investigations into the [[IRS targeting controversy]] were held by the [[United States House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform|House Oversight Committee]], chaired by [[Jason Chaffetz]]. Koskinen was instructed to protect and turn over all records relating to the controversy. However, under Koskinen, the vast amount of documentation, including computer backup tapes, were destroyed. Chaffetz issued a document to begin [[impeachment]] proceedings against Koskinen saying, "he failed to comply with a congressionally issued subpoena, documents were destroyed on his watch, and the public was consistently misled. Impeachment is the appropriate tool to restore public confidence in the IRS and to protect the institutional interests of Congress."{{cite news|title=House Republicans introduce measure to impeach IRS Commissioner Koskinen|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2015/10/27/house-republicans-introduce-measure-to-impeach-irs-commissioner-koskinen.html|accessdate=June 10, 2017|agency=Fox News Politics|date=October 27, 2015}} However, Republican House leadership did not bring the impeachment to the floor for a vote.{{cite news|title=IRS boss Koskinen takes heat at impeachment hearing for faulty testimony|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2016/09/21/irs-boss-koskinen-admits-failings-at-impeachment-hearing.html|accessdate=June 10, 2017|agency=Fox News Politics|date=September 21, 2016}} With the support of the House [[Freedom Caucus]], Fleming utilized a rarely-used [[parliamentary procedure]] called a [[privileged motion]]{{cite web|title=Robert's Rules|url=http://www.rulesonline.com/rror-03.htm|website=RulesOnline.com|accessdate=June 10, 2017}} to force a vote on impeachment of Koskinen. Fleming went to the floor of the House and read the motion on July 13, 2016, after filing it in writing the day before.{{cite news|last1=Bade|first1=Rachael|title=Freedom Caucus goes all-in on IRS impeachment|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/07/freedom-caucus-files-irs-impeachment-measure-225498|accessdate=June 10, 2017|agency=Politico|date=July 13, 2017}} Though the motion required a vote on impeachment, House leadership and the Freedom Caucus negotiated a compromise for Koskinen to return for an additional hearing to learn more about his actions in the scandal. Koskinen returned, voluntarily, on September 21, 2016, to face an impeachment hearing during which he admitted to his "failings" in getting to the bottom of the [[IRS targeting controversy]].Richard Rainey, [http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2016/09/louisiana_rep_john_fleming_cal.html Louisiana Rep. John Fleming calls for vote to impeach IRS commissioner], ''Times-Picayune'' (September 13, 2016).Richard Rainey, [http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2016/09/rep_john_fleming-led_vote_to_i.html Rep. John Fleming-led vote to impeach IRS commissioner on hold], ''Times-Picayune'' (September 15, 2016). ==== Social media to connect with constituents ==== As Fleming entered Congress in 2009, use of [[social media]] such as [[Facebook]] and [[Twitter]] emerged as methods for members to connect directly with their constituents. In 2010 the [[Republican Conference of the United States House of Representatives|House Republican Conference]] created the "New Media Challenge" to spur Republican members to acquire more followers. Fleming was awarded first place in both 2010 ad 2011 by his Republican peers.{{cite news|last1=Moire|first1=Jennifer|title=Who's Winning The Facebook War On Capitol Hill?|url=http://www.adweek.com/digital/whos-winning-the-facebook-war-on-capitol-hill/ |agency=Adweek |date=July 8, 2011 |accessdate=June 9, 2017}} ====Work on religion in the military==== Beginning about 2005, critics claimed that Christians in the military caught [[proselytism|proselytizing]] should be [[court-martial]]ed. Subsequently, military members came forward claiming they were being punished by their military superiors for what they viewed as reasonable religious expression, a violation of the [[First Amendment]].{{cite web|last1=Bowers|first1=Becky|title=Bloggers say Pentagon may court-martial Christian soldiers|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2013/may/06/blog-posting/bloggers-say-pentagon-may-court-martial-christian-/|website=Politifact|accessdate=June 20, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Yu|first1=Annie|title=Christians under siege push for more freedom of expression in military|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2013/jul/17/proponents-of-religion-push-for-more-freedom-of-ex/|accessdate=June 20, 2017|agency=Washington Times|date=July 17, 2013}} In June 2013, Fleming sponsored an amendment to the 2014 [[National Defense Authorization Act]] requiring the military "to accommodate, except in cases of military necessity, actions and speech, reflecting the conscience, moral principles, or religious beliefs of the member." The amendment drew objections from the White House, with a spokesman saying that commanders need discretion to, "address potentially problematic speech and actions within their units" and that the measure would "have a significant adverse effect on good order, discipline, morale and mission accomplishment." The amendment passed with a bipartisan vote by the [[United States House Committee on Armed Services|House Armed Services Committee]]. A similar measure passed the Senate and compromise language was adopted into the final [[National Defense Authorization Act|NDAA]] signed into law.{{cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2013/06/fleming_proposal_to_require_fr.html/|title=Fleming proposal to require free religious expression in military draws White House objections|publisher=The Times-Picayune|date=June 12, 2013}} The Army [[Chaplain]] Corps was implemented July 29, 1775, by George Washington, then the general of the [[Continental Army]]. Of chaplains Washington said, "Common decency, Sir, in a camp calls for the services of a divine, and which ought not to be dispensed with, altho' the world should be so uncharitable as to think us void of religion, and incapable of good instructions."{{cite web|title=George Washington on Chaplain's Importance Thereof|url=http://www.ministers-best-friend.com/George-Washington-on-CHAPLAINS-IMPORTANCE-Thereof.html|website=Ministers-best-friend.com|accessdate=June 20, 2017}} By definition a [[chaplain]] is a religious minister assigned to a secular institution. During 2013, attempts were made by an atheist to join the military as a chaplain.{{cite news|last1=Tilghaman|first1=Andrew|title=Navy lawyers defend rejection of atheist chaplain|url=http://www.militarytimes.com/story/military/2015/06/18/navy-lawyers-defend-rejection-of-atheist-chaplain-jason-heap-humanist-humanism/28937925/|accessdate=June 20, 2017|agency=Military Times|date=June 18, 2015}} In July 2013, the U.S. House passed a measure, sponsored by Fleming, that bars the Defense Department from appointing atheist chaplains. Fleming said, "The notion of an atheist chaplain is nonsensical; it's an oxymoron." Democratic Congressman [[Rob Andrews]] of New Jersey said that it was "wrong" to tell an [[Irreligion|irreligious]] service member that they "must go to a mental health professional in order to receive counseling, rather than someone who comes from their philosophical faith or tradition."{{cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2013/07/house_passes_fleming_measure_t.html|title=House passes Rep. John Fleming's measure to ban atheist military chaplains|work=The Times-Picayune|date=July 24, 2013}} Fleming ended the debate by saying, "an atheist chaplain is the last person in the world that a dying soldier should meet with when they need that last moment of counseling in their life." The amendment passed into the [[Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2014|2014 House DOD appropriations bill]]{{cite news|last1=Kasperowicz|first1=Pete|title=House votes to block DOD from hiring nonreligious chaplains|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/house/313049-house-votes-to-block-dod-from-hiring-non-religious-chaplains|accessdate=June 20, 2017|agency=The Hill|date=July 24, 2013}} For his work on religious freedom and material support of the military chaplaincy during his tenure on the House Armed Services Committee, Fleming was given the first ever Torchbearer for Religious Freedom award in 2014 by the Chaplain Alliance for Religious Liberty.{{cite news|title=Fleming receives Religious Freedom Award from military chaplains|url=http://bossierpress.com/fleming-receives-religious-freedom-award-from-military-chaplains/|accessdate=19 November 2017|agency=Bossier Press-Tribune|publisher=bossierpress.com|date=2 October 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Bob|first1=Eschlman|title=Congressman Awarded for Dedication to Military's Religious Liberty|url=https://www.charismanews.com/politics/issues/58593-congressman-awarded-for-dedication-to-military-s-religious-liberty|website=Charisma News|accessdate=19 November 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Cavalier|first1=Richard|title=Chairman, member of House Armed Services Committee to receive Chaplain Alliance Torchbearer Award|url=http://chaplainalliance.org/site/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/2014-09-25-Chaplain-Alliance-News-Release.pdf|website=Chaplain Alliance for Religious Freedom|accessdate=19 November 2017}} ====Long Range Strike Caucus==== In 2009 Fleming stood up and co-chaired this bipartisan congressional caucus to "sustain both the land- and sea-based long range strike capabilities."{{cite news|last1=Tasista|first1=Michelle|title=Global Strike commander talks long-range strike|url=http://www.afgsc.af.mil/News/Article-Display/Article/455138/global-strike-commander-talks-long-range-strike/|agency=Air Force Global Strike Command|date=April 19, 2011 |accessdate=June 9, 2017}} ====Congressional [[Addiction, Treatment and Recovery Caucus]]==== Fleming, based on his training, experience and interest, was the Republican co-chair of this bipartisan congressional caucus that promotes addiction treatment and prevention.{{cite news|last1=Slaton|first1=Hunter|title=Two Congressmen Talk Addiction With The Fix|url=https://www.thefix.com/content/congressional-addiction-treatment-recovery-caucus-interview00416?page=all|accessdate=31 August 2017|agency=The Fix|date=May 13, 2013}} ====[[United States House of Representatives|House]] Values Action Team (VAT)==== Fleming served as co-chair of VAT, a [[United States House of Representatives|House]] caucus, that met regularly with interest groups in support of legislation and court decisions that are [[United States pro-life movement|pro-life]] and [[Family values|pro-traditional family]].{{cite web|title=Hartzler, Pitts, Fleming to POTUS: mandate treats children as pawns in political agenda; urge withdrawal|url=https://hartzler.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/hartzler-pitts-fleming-potus-mandate-treats-children-pawns-political|website=Rep. Vicky Hartzler|date=May 13, 2016|accessdate=June 10, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Newhauser|first1=Daniel|title=House Conservatives Are Pushing Leadership for Antiabortion Language in New Spending Bill|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2014/12/house-conservatives-are-pushing-leadership-for-antiabortion-language-in-new-spending-bill/451698/|accessdate=June 10, 2017|agency=The Atlantic|date=December 4, 2014}} ====2012 abortion post ==== In 2012, Fleming attracted attention for sharing an article from the satirical news source ''[[The Onion]]'' (titled "Planned Parenthood Opens $8 Billion Abortionplex") with his Facebook followers with the apparently sincere message, "More on Planned Parenthood, abortion by wholesale". He deleted the post after commenters highlighted the article's satirical nature.{{Cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2012/02/rep-fleming-skinned-by-the-onion-072507|title=Congressman links to Onion story|work=Politico|accessdate=March 25, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.theonion.com/article/planned-parenthood-opens-8-billion-abortionplex-20476|title=Planned Parenthood Opens $8 Billion Abortionplex|date=May 18, 2011 |accessdate=March 23, 2017|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2012/02/congressman-falls-months-old-onion-story-about-planned-parenthood-abortionplex/332189/|title=Congressman Falls for The Onion's Planned Parenthood 'Abortionplex' Story|last=Grandoni|first=Dino|work=The Atlantic|accessdate=March 23, 2017|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/john-fleming-onion-real-politican-posts-link-fake-news-planned-parenthood-facebook-article-1.1018018|title=Oops! Politician posts link to The Onion|work=NY Daily News|accessdate=March 25, 2017 |language=en}} ====[[Budget Control Act of 2011]] and [[United States budget sequestration in 2013|budget sequestration of 2013]]==== After Republicans took control of the [[United States House of Representatives]] In 2011, a debate emerged over how to bring deficit spending under control after it ballooned to over $1.3 trillion annually from 2009-2011.{{cite web|last1=de Rugy|first1=Veronique|title=Debt and Deficit under Obama Administration|url=https://www.mercatus.org/publications/debt-and-deficit-under-obama-administration|website=George Mason University|accessdate=June 7, 2017}} A compromise deal was struck, called the [[Budget Control Act of 2011]], between Republican [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker]] [[John Boehner]] and [[President Obama]] that would create a [[bipartisan]] and [[bicameral]] [[United States Congress Joint Select Committee on Deficit Reduction|"super committee"]] in Congress to decide how to equitably lower [[discretionary spending]]. According to the act, automatic and substantial cuts would be made to both national defense and non-defense [[discretionary spending]] in the federal budget if the committee did not come to an agreement to specific and targeted budget cuts. The [[United States Congress Joint Select Committee on Deficit Reduction|"super committee"]] could not come to an agreement leading to the automatic cuts to national defense and domestic spending. Fleming opposed and voted against the [[Budget Control Act of 2011]] as he feared it would ultimately lead to devastating cuts to national defense, which it did.{{cite news|last1=Bash|first1=Dana|title=House approves budget deal aimed at averting shutdown|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/12/12/politics/congress-budget/index.html|accessdate=June 7, 2017|agency=CNN.com|date=December 12, 2013}}{{cite news|title=Congressman Fleming opposes Pentagon proposal to make further cuts to US Military|url=http://louisianaradionetwork.com/blogs/john-fleming-opposes-more-cuts-to-US-military-under-pentagon-proposal#.WTdS-xPys0o|accessdate=June 7, 2017|date=February 24, 2014}}{{cite news|title=Military warns cuts would create 'hollow force' akin to 1970s|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2013/feb/10/military-warns-cuts-would-create-hollow-force-akin/|accessdate=June 7, 2017|agency=Washington Times|date=February 10, 2013}}{{cite news|last1=Cohen|first1=Zachary|title=Desperate for planes, military turns to the 'boneyard'|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/07/13/politics/military-aircraft-boneyard/index.html|accessdate=June 7, 2017|agency=CNN Politics|issue=July 14, 2016}}{{cite web|title=The U.S. Military Is Suffering A Crisis Of Strategy, Not Just One Of Readiness|url=http://nationalinterest.org/blog/the-buzz/the-us-military-suffering-crisis-strategy-not-just-one-20918|website=The Natural Interest|accessdate=June 7, 2017}} Fleming was quoted in ''[[Forbes]]'' as saying: "Republicans in general, we desperately want a reduction in spending to get government back into balance. We would rather take some cuts in areas that we are not comfortable with than have no cuts at all."{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/lorenthompson/2013/02/04/republicans-target-their-own-voters-in-defense-budget-switch/|work=Forbes|title=Republicans Target Their Own Voters In Defense Budget Switch|last=Thompson|first=Loren|date=February 4, 2013|accessdate=March 6, 2013}} ''Forbes'' noted that Fleming's district includes [[Barksdale Air Force Base]] and [[Fort Polk]], both major military installations. At a discussion in February 2013 in [[DeRidder, Louisiana|DeRidder]]; Fleming, a military veteran, stated he would not vote to allow the government to cut $600 million from the defense budget.[http://www.beauregarddailynews.net/article/20130221/NEWS/130229892?refresh=true Fleming speaks about budget, Fort Polk at town hall meeting – News – Beauregard Daily News – Beauregard, LA] Fleming was well-known to be a supporter of the military and its personnel and the need to reverse the devastating cuts since the [[Budget Control Act of 2011]] was implemented.{{cite web|title=Fleming: We've Got To Begin Taking Our Defense Seriously |url=http://thehayride.com/2016/08/fleming-weve-got-to-begin-taking-our-defense-seriously/|website=The Hayride|accessdate=May 30, 2017}}{{cite web|title=John Fleming on Homeland Security |url=http://www.ontheissues.org/International/John_Fleming_Homeland_Security.htm|website=On the Issues|accessdate=May 30, 2017}}{{cite web|title=Changes on the Hill - Vets in Congress |url=http://www.moaa.org/Content/Take-Action/Top-Issues/Currently-Serving/Changes-on-the-Hill---Vets-in-Congress.aspx|website=MOAA|accessdate=May 30, 2017}} He was quoted as saying, "One way my service in the military changes the way I do my job is that I understand our next conflict is not a matter of 'if' but 'when,' and that we need to equip our military with the resources and tools they need to protect our nation at home and abroad."{{cite web|title=Congress at War|url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2015/06/congress-vets-quotes-119264_full.html#.WSzOjBMrI0o|website=Politico Magazine|accessdate=May 30, 2017}}{{cite web|title=John Fleming on Homeland Security|url=http://www.ontheissues.org/International/John_Fleming_Homeland_Security.htm|website=On the Issues|accessdate=May 30, 2017}} Fleming voted against the [[Budget Control Act of 2011]],{{USHVote|2011|690}} that caused the automatic budget sequestration in March 2013. On November 21, 2011, Fleming criticized the Budget Control Act because of what he called "devastating cuts to military spending."[http://fleming.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=270058 Fleming Responds to Failure of Debt Reduction Committee | Congressman John Fleming] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130216110444/http://fleming.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=270058 |date=February 16, 2013 }} On June 12, 2017, the newly confirmed Secretary of Defense, [[Jim Mattis]], said of [[United States budget sequestration in 2013|Sequestration]], "(he) was 'shocked' upon his return to the Pentagon by the poor state of the U.S. military's readiness for combat." He was further quoted as saying, "(DoD) needs years to correct effects of Sequestration."{{cite news|title=Defense Secretary Mattis "shocked" by poor state of U.S. combat readiness|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/defense-secretary-jim-mattis-shocked-by-poor-state-of-us-combat-readiness/|accessdate=June 15, 2017|agency=CBS News|date=June 12, 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Garamone|first1=Jim|title=Mattis Says DoD Needs Years to Correct Effects of Sequestration|url=https://www.defense.gov/News/Article/Article/1213034/mattis-says-dod-needs-years-to-correct-effects-of-sequestration/|website=U.S. Department of Defense|accessdate=June 15, 2017}} ===Political positions=== ====Abortion==== Fleming was a staunch advocate in protecting unborn human life. He voted against taxpayer funding of abortion through the [[Affordable Care Act]], [[Planned Parenthood]] and other programs that fund abortion through federal tax dollars. He opposed the use of abortion to choose sex, gender, color or race of the child, or the race of a parent.{{cite web|title=Fleming on Abortion|url=http://www.ontheissues.org/House/John_Fleming_Abortion.htm|website=On the Issues|accessdate=June 16, 2017}} ====Religious liberty==== In support of religious liberty and right of conscience, Fleming supported the company, [[Hobby Lobby]], in its position to refuse to fund, through its healthcare insurance program, abortion or [[abortifacients]] for its employees under the [[Affordable Care Act]]. The [[Supreme Court of the United States]] ultimately ruled in favor of Hobby Lobby. He also opposed military sanctions against its members for openly expressing religious views.{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/chris-rodda/rep-fleming-ndaa-religiou_b_4461318.html|title=Rep. Fleming: NDAA Religious Freedom Language Not a 'Touchdown' -- New Talking Points Needed|last=Rodda|first=Chris|date=2013-12-17|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-13}}{{cite web|title=Defense Department Issues New Rules on Religious Liberty in the Military|url=https://www.cmrlink.org/articles/print/37405?author=0&image=0&domain=0|website=Center for Military Readiness}} ====Opposition to same-sex marriage==== In 2012, before the ''[[Obergefell v. Hodges]]'' Supreme Court decision, Fleming condemned a marriage-like ceremony that took place at [[Fort Polk, Louisiana]], between an enlisted woman and civilian woman. (Fort Polk, a [[U.S. Army base]], lies within Fleming's congressional district.) Fleming said that the ceremony "should not have occurred at Fort Polk, especially since the people of Louisiana have made it abundantly clear that our state does not recognize same-sex marriages or civil unions" and characterized the event as part of a "liberal social experiment with our military."Alan Duke, [http://www.cnn.com/2012/06/07/us/army-same-sex-ceremony/ Same-sex ceremony on Army post draws fire], CNN (June 7, 2012). Fleming condemned the Supreme Court's 2015 decision of ''Obergefell v. Hodges'', which found a constitutional right to [[Same-sex marriage in the United States|same-sex marriage]]. Fleming stated that he was "greatly disappointed" and disagreed with the decision.Bruce Alpert, [http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2015/06/louisiana_gop_congressional_me.html Louisiana GOP congressional members condemn ruling for gay marriage, Democrats say it advances freedom], ''[[The Times-Picayune]]'' (June 26, 2015). Fleming was also a co-sponsor of The [[First Amendment Defense Act]], a bill designed to protect religious institutions from being forced to perform marriage or other ceremonies that violate their teachings.{{cite web|author1=Bruch Alpert|title=Supporters of bill to protect rights of same-sex marriage foes open to compromise|url=http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2015/07/supporters_of_bill_to_protects.html|newspaper=The Times-Picayune|date=July 23, 2013}} ===Committee assignments=== Upon his election to the [[United States House of Representatives]], Fleming was assigned to these committees: * [[United States House Committee on Armed Services|Committee on Armed Services]], ** [[United States House Armed Services Subcommittee on Tactical Air and Land Forces|Subcommittee on Tactical Air and Land Forces]] ** [[United States House Armed Services Subcommittee on Strategic Forces|Subcommittee on Strategic Forces]]; * [[United States House Committee on Natural Resources|Committee on Natural Resources]], ** [[United States House Natural Resources Subcommittee on Energy and Mineral Resources|Subcommittee on Energy and Mineral Resources]] ** [[United States House Natural Resources Subcommittee on Fisheries, Wildlife, Oceans and Insular Affairs|Subcommittee on Fisheries, Wildlife, Oceans and Insular Affairs]] (Chairman) ===Caucus memberships=== * The [[Republican Study Committee]] * The [[Tea Party Caucus]] * Co-chair of the [[Addiction, Treatment and Recovery Caucus|Congressional Addiction, Treatment and Recovery Caucus]] *Co-chair of the House Values Action Team (VAT){{cite web|title=Rep. Vicky Hartzler|url=https://hartzler.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/hartzler-pitts-fleming-potus-mandate-treats-children-pawns-political|accessdate=June 10, 2017}} * Co-founder of the [[House Freedom Caucus]]{{Cite news|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/412775/meet-freedom-caucus-joel-gehrke|title=Meet the Freedom Caucus|work=National Review|accessdate=March 25, 2017 |language=en}} * Co-chair of the GOP Doctors Caucus{{Cite news|url=http://insurancenewsnet.com/oarticle/Dr-Fleming-named-new-Co-Chair-for-GOP-Doctors-Caucus-a-569551|title=Dr. Fleming named new Co-Chair for GOP Doctors Caucus|date=October 20, 2014 |work=InsuranceNewsNet|accessdate=March 25, 2017|language=en-US}} *Co-chair and founder of the Long Range Strike Caucus * [[Congressional Constitution Caucus]]{{cite web|title=Members|author=|url=https://congressionalconstitutioncaucus-garrett.house.gov/about-us/membership|format=|publisher=Congressional Constitution Caucus|date=|accessdate=8 May 2018}} *'''[[Congressional Arts Caucus]]'''{{cite web|title=Membership|author=|url=https://artscaucus-slaughter.house.gov/membership|format=|publisher=Congressional Arts Caucus|date=|accessdate=13 March 2018}} ==See also== * [[Physicians in the United States Congress]] ==Health and Human Services tenure== After completing four terms in the [[United States House of Representatives]], Dr. Fleming was appointed Deputy Secretary of Health Technology Reform in [[Health and Human Services]] on March 23, 2017, by [[President Donald Trump]]. On being appointed, Fleming said, "I just want to be a part of taking down the barriers that are preventing innovation (in healthcare)."{{cite news|last1=Rainey|first1=Richard|title=Former Louisiana Rep. John Fleming to join HHS under Trump|url=http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2017/03/former_louisiana_rep_john_flem.html |accessdate=May 30, 2017|date=March 20, 2017}} During his private medical practice work, Fleming was an early adopter of (EHRs) [[Electronic Health Records]]. He implemented his first system in 1997 and said his practice was fully [[paperless office|paperless]] by 1999.{{cite web|title=Leadership Bios|url=https://www.healthit.gov/newsroom/john-fleming-md|website=HealthIT.gov|accessdate=May 29, 2017}} He was assigned, primarily, to the [[Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology|Office of the National Coordinator]], an agency within HHS. Fleming noted that for years after implementing his EHR, adoption rates of EHRs among his healthcare colleagues remained low until the implementation of the [[Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act|HITECH Act]] in 2009 in which around $30 billion in cash incentives were used to encourage [[health professionals]] to purchase EHRs. He reported that by 2017 adoption rates among hospitals was over 95% and over 85% among physician offices.{{cite news|last1=Leventhal|first1=Rajiv|title=HHS' New Health IT Lead Speaks Out on EHR Usability, Interoperability|url=https://www.healthcare-informatics.com/article/interoperability/hhs-new-health-it-lead-speaks-out-ehr-usability-interoperability|accessdate=May 29, 2017|date=May 25, 2017}} Fleming has been a strong advocate of technology [[innovation]] and believes "the future of healthcare technology is tied to two core goals: improving the [[usability]] of health IT systems and [[interoperability]]." He also stated that [[interoperability]] "would be sparked by every American having a single, unified health record that resides in the cloud." He lamented the problems with the current [[fractionated]] nature of EHRs being disbursed among a myriad of healthcare providers tends to defeat the purpose of [[information technology]] to improve access to medical information and [[healthcare]] in general.{{cite news|title=Former Rep. Fleming Named to HHS Health Technology Post |url=https://ehrintelligence.com/news/former-rep.-fleming-named-to-hhs-health-technology-post |date=March 21, 2017 |accessdate=May 30, 2017}} Related to technology, Fleming advocated (ACOs) [[accountable care organization]]s as a method to streamline healthcare purchasing instead of the traditional [[fee for service]] system still mostly used today. Of [[fee for service]] Fleming said, "If you're paying for service, you'll get service, whether the outcomes are good or not." He has supported the need to produce and use data to improve the quality and [[cost effectiveness]] of healthcare as evidenced by the statement, "how do you pay for outcomes without good data? We need better methods for getting data into the system and delivering it to you, and we're working on doing that. There is a good marriage between [[Pay for performance (healthcare)|pay-for-value]] and data". ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Portalbar|Biography|Mississippi|South Carolina|California|Louisiana|United States Navy|Medicine|Business and Economics|Books|Politics|Conservatism|Government of the United States|Baptist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * {{Dmoz|Regional/North_America/United_States/Louisiana/Government/Federal/US_House_of_Representatives/John_Fleming_%5BR-4%5D|John Fleming}} * {{C-SPAN|1031345}} * {{CongLinks | congbio=F000456 | votesmart=108811 | fec=H8LA04225 | congress=john-fleming/1924 }} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{s-bef|before=[[Jim McCrery]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Member of the [[List of United States Representatives from Louisiana|U.S. House of Representatives]]

[[File:Bachstitz Walter portrait by Arnold Genthe (1923).png|thumb|Portrait of Kurt Walter Bachstitz by [[Arnold Genthe]], 1923.]] '''Kurt Walter Bachstitz''' (4 October 1882 – 1949 in [[The Hague]]) was a [[Germany|German]]-[[Austrians|Austrian]] [[art dealer]]. He died shortly before his naturalization to the [[Netherlands]].<ref name="libmma">{{cite web|url=http://libmma.org/digital_files/archives/Bachstitz_records_b18041048.pdf|title=Bachstitz, Inc. records, 1923-1937|publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art Archives|accessdate=2015-06-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.restitutiecommissie.nl/adviezen/advies_178.html|title=Bachstitz, Restitution Commission of the Netherlands, Az RC 1.78, Consideration No.2|accessdate=2015-06-11}}</ref>
==General Information==
===Until Emigration 1938=== Bachstitz was born as the child of the Jewish couple Liber Jacob Bachstitz and Mathilde Markowitz. His place of birth is arguable. All contemporary sources mention the formerly German [[Breslau]] (the present-day Polish [[Wrocław]]) as his place of birth.<ref>NA, Ministry of Justice, naturalization files, access code 2.09.22, inv. no. 13533, no. 2189; Central Bureau for Genealogy, The Hague, Calmery archive, Bachstitz file</ref> But Bachstitz requested for himself the Austrian village Raipoltenbach as his place of birth when he claimed at the U.S. Department of Labor for an extension of his temporary stay in 1931.<ref name="libmma"/> He studied architecture in [[Paris]], [[London]] and [[Vienna]] where he finished his studies with a diploma. On the outbreak of the [[First World War]] he was called up for military service and served between 1914 and 1918 as an officer, lastly in the rank of a troop captain. He served actively in the field until 1916, when he was severely wounded.<ref>NA, Ministry of Justice, naturalization files, access code 2.09.22, inv. no. 13533, no. 2189</ref> He married Elfriede Pesé (died in 1918) with whom he had two children – a son Walter Werner Michael who died in 1943 by tuberculosis in [[Switzerland]] and a daughter, Margit Martha<ref>File RC 1.78, estate inventory (via Ministry of Finance, inheritance tax returns)</ref> who died in [[South Africa]] in 1982. On 19 December 1918 he married his second wife Elisa ("Lilly") Emma Hofer. Lilly was a [[Protestant]]. Because of her Bachstitz converted to the evangelic faith.<ref>NA, SNK 178, Bachstitz file, draft letter from Bogisch to Weyma, undated</ref> In 1919 he apparently lived and traded in Munich. In his diary [[Thomas Mann]] wrote about a meeting in Bachstitz' Munich apartment, where Mann bought a work from Bachstitz. He described him quite prerogatively as a "blond-Jewish" example of an "international culture-capitalistic profiteer".<ref>Thomas Mann Tagebücher, 1918–1921, herausgegeben von Peter de Mendelssohn, Frankfurt/M. 1979, {{ISBN|978-3-10-048192-4}}, S. 143 – 145 '"Der Mensch, blond-jüdisch und elegant, Mitte dreißig, mit Monokel und fetten, weißen, manikürten Händen, in gesteppter Hausjacke und Lackhausschuhen, wunderbar als Typus des international-kultur-kapitalistischen Schiebertums."</ref> In 1920 he established an art dealership in the Hague named Kunsthandel K.W. Bachstitz (Bachstitz Gallery N.V.). Surinamestraat 11, He lived in Vienna and in [[Berlin]] and he created an internationally known company with art galleries in The Hague, [[New York City]] and Berlin. Lilly was the sister of art dealer [[Walter Hofer|Walter Andreas Hofer]] who had managed the Gallery in The Hague for a while and subsequently became an art buyer for [[Hermann Göring]].
In 1937 Bachstitz waived his Austrian citizenship. In 1938 the couple moved to The Hague.<ref name="libmma"/>
===World War II===
Between the beginning of the German occupation in 1940 and 1941 Bachstitz sold a number of paintings to the "[[:de:Sonderauftrag Linz|Sondernauftrag Linz]]" that was run by [[Hitler]]'s Special Representative of the planned '[[Führermuseum]]' in Linz,<ref>Looted Art Commission. [http://www.lootedartcommission.com/RWN60N12704]"Munich's Looted Art Bazaar Sueddeutsche Zeitung 25 June 2016, 25 June 2016 Von Catrin Lorch und Jörg Häntzschelz"</ref> [[Hans Posse]]<ref name="archives">{{cite web|url=https://www.archives.gov/publications/prologue/2002/summer/nazi-looted-art-1.html|title=Prologue: Selected Articles|publisher=archives.gov|accessdate=2015-06-11}}</ref> until his death in 1942.
Among the works sold to the Sonderauftrag were the following: *[[Ferdinand Bol]] "The Angel of the Lord appears unto Gideon" [http://www.herkomstgezocht.nl/web/scripts/wwwopac.exe?%250=1732&LANGUAGE=0 NK 2484][[File:MCC-41266 Offer van Gideon (1).jpg|thumb|Ferdinand Bol "The Angel of the Lord appears unto Gideon" NK 2484]] *[[Stephan Godl]] "Adam and Eve" [http://www.herkomstgezocht.nl/web/scripts/wwwopac.exe?%250=3634&LANGUAGE=0 NK 636-a-b]
The correspondence between Bachstitz and Posse concerning these works is preserved. Posse achieved high price reductions.<ref> [https://de.m.wikisource.org/wiki/Briefe_Bachstitz Wikisource: Korrespondenz Bachstitz Juli 1940] [https://commons.Wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Blatt_360.png Wikicommons]</ref>
*Greek / Tanagra Figure "Standing Woman" [http://www.herkomstgezocht.nl/web/scripts/wwwopac.exe?%250=3617&LANGUAGE=0 NK 620]; [http://www.rmo.nl/collectie/zoeken?object=I+1953%2f3.1 RMO, Leiden]; [http://www.dhm.de/datenbank/ccp/dhm_ccp_add.php?seite=6&fld_1=12272&fld_1_exakt=exakt&suchen=Suchen&LANGUAGE=0 CCP-Database] *[[Girolamo da Santa Croce]] "Saint John the Baptist" [http://www.herkomstgezocht.nl/web/scripts/wwwopac.exe?%250=731&LANGUAGE=0 NK 1627] *German (Cologne) "A small altar with saints and two scenes" [http://www.herkomstgezocht.nl/web/scripts/wwwopac.exe?%250=1984&LANGUAGE=0 NK 2707] *German (also Alpian) "St. Mary and St. John before the Crucifixion" [http://www.herkomstgezocht.nl/web/scripts/wwwopac.exe?%250=640&LANGUAGE=0 NK 1552] *Greek Snake Bracelets [http://www.herkomstgezocht.nl/web/scripts/wwwopac.exe?%250=4143&LANGUAGE=0 NK 864-a-b] *Greek Carnelian Engraved Gem [http://www.herkomstgezocht.nl/web/scripts/wwwopac.exe?%250=2257&LANGUAGE=0NK 2904] *[[Gerrit Berckheyde]] "Grote Markt with Cathedral St. Bavo in Haarlem" [http://www.herkomstgezocht.nl/web/scripts/wwwopac.exe?%250=1840&LANGUAGE=0 NK 2581]; [http://www.dhm.de/datenbank/ccp/dhm_ccp_add.php?seite=6&fld_3=1298&fld_3_exakt=exakt&suchen=Suchen CCP-Database]; [http://www.franshalsmuseum.nl/nl/collectie/zoeken-de-collectie/de-grote-markt-te-haarlem-met-de-grote-of-st-bavokerk-114/ Frans Hals Museum, Haarlem][[File:Berkheyde-Haarlem.jpg|thumb|Gerrit Berckheyde "Grote Markt with Cathedral St. Bavo in Haarlem" NK 2581]] *[[Alexander Colin]] "Heavenly Apparition over a Town" [http://www.herkomstgezocht.nl/web/scripts/wwwopac.exe?%250=3629&LANGUAGE=0 NK 631] *[[Giovanni Antonio Canal|Canaletto]] (copy after) "The return of the Bucintoro to the Molo on Ascension day" [http://www.herkomstgezocht.nl/web/scripts/wwwopac.exe?%250=932&LANGUAGE=0 NK 1798] *[[Jan van Scorel]] "St. Paul" [http://www.herkomstgezocht.nl/web/scripts/wwwopac.exe?%250=2273&LANGUAGE=0 NK 2919] *[[Pietro Cappelli]] "Roman Capriccio" [http://www.herkomstgezocht.nl/web/scripts/wwwopac.exe?%250=1047&LANGUAGE=0 NK 1892] *Greek Golden bracelet with Serapis head, 1st century [http://www.dhm.de/datenbank/ccp/dhm_ccp_add.php?seite=6&fld_3=3872a&fld_3_exakt=exakt&suchen=Suchen NK 865/CCP-Database], [http://www.rmo.nl/collectie/zoeken?object=F+1953%2f4.2 RMO, Leiden] *Surrounding of Giovanni di Francesco del Cervelliera Frame [http://www.herkomstgezocht.nl/web/scripts/wwwopac.exe?%250=915&LANGUAGE=0 NK1787] *[[François Duquesnoy]] "Cupido" (attribution: Venice, 16th century) [http://www.dhm.de/datenbank/ccp/dhm_ccp.php?seite=6&fld_1=13132&fld_3=&auswahl=6&fld_4=&fld_4a=&fld_5=&fld_6=&fld_7=&fld_8=&fld_9=&fld_10=&suchen=SuchenLANGUAGE=0 CCP-Database] *Greek "standing woman 'the night' (Nyx)" [http://www.dhm.de/datenbank/ccp/dhm_ccp_add.php?seite=6&fld_3=1365&fld_3_exakt=exakt&suchen=Suchen CCP-Database]; [http://www.getty.edu/art/gettyguide/artObjectDetails?artobj=35437 Getty Villa Malibu]
In February 1941 Bachstitz officially resigned as supervisory director of the Bachstitz Gallery and his wife became the managing director. Together with his wife, he continued to provide a clandestine management role. In this way, they avoided having the Gallery placed under the forced administration for the duration of the war. According to the documents in the file concerning his successful application to become a Dutchman after the war<ref>NL-NA, ministerie van justitie (1915–1955), inv. No. 13533 (1646)</ref> the couple provided undercover protection for Jews trying to escape the authorities.
In 1942 Bachstitz was summoned by the occupation authority (the "Wirtschaftsamt") as he had failed to register the gallery as "non-Aryan property". Proceedings were commenced against him and he was arrested by the [[Sicherheitsdienst]] (SD) in July 1943 and imprisoned in the Scheveningen prison in The Hague. Due to an intervention of Göring initiated by Bachstitz' brother-in-law Hofer, he was released from prison. He was then also exempted from wearing the Star of David. Furthermore, the couple had their marriage dissolved in September 1943 to prevent the confiscation of the gallery by the occupying authority.
Between 1942 und 1944 Bachstitz sold a number of works to the museums that were run by [[Kurt Martin]], the head of the Museums of the Upper Rhine (Alsace and Baden) under [[Robert Heinrich Wagner]].<ref>[http://www.lostart.de/Webs/DE/Datenbank/SucheMeldungDetail.html?resourceId=4348&input_=4340&pageLocale=de&person=&titelbesch=&datierung=&objektart=-1&objektart.GROUP=1&mattech=&provsamml=kurt+martin&institution=&ort=&id=&type=DetailVerlust&type.GROUP=1&suche_typ=MeldungDetail&suche_typ.HASH=01c6e21bb090266af660&suchen=Suchen 10 Search Requests at www.lostart.de, latest view June 11, 2015]</ref>
In 1944 Bachstitz managed to obtain permission to leave the Netherlands and he emigrated to Switzerland, again with the help of Andreas Hofer.<ref name="libmma"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.restitutiecommissie.nl/adviezen/advies_178.html|title=Bachstitz, Restitution Commission of the Netherlands, Az RC 1.78, Consideration No.6|accessdate=2015-06-11}}</ref>
As a bribe for the exit visa Bachstitz had to hand over art to Hermann Göring, namely a painting with the Samson and Delilah motive by [[Jan Steen]],<ref>US-NARA, RG 260, M1946. Roll 127. Restitution Research Records. Göring, Hermann: Notes on Purchases. Page 65.</ref> as well two antique necklaces.<ref name="lootedart">{{cite web|url=http://www.lootedart.com/aliu-long_print;Y|title=Post-War Reports: Art Looting Intelligence Unit (ALIU) Reports 1945-1946 and ALIU Red Flag Names List and Index|publisher=lootedart.com|accessdate=2015-06-11}}</ref>
===After The War - Successful and Unsuccessful Restitution Efforts===
After the war the Allies returned most of the art that the gallery had sold to German authorities to the Netherlands. The Netherlands restituted the painting by Jan Steen<ref>NL-NA, Stichting Nederlands Kunstbezit (SNK), 2.08.42.</ref> but rejected an application for the restitution of the other works. They became part of the Collection of the Stichting Nederlands Kunstbezit (SNK). Kurt Walter Bachsitz and Lilly Bachstitz-Hofer were again registered as officially married. Kurt Walter Bachstitz died in 1949. In 1951 his widow liquidated the Bachstitz Gallery N.V. with a high deficit.<ref>NL-NA 2.09.16, Nederlands Beheers Instituut NBI, inv.no. 2168, Note Kesselaar NBI 16 December 1955.</ref> The gallery's art library was auctioned off.<ref name="archive">{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/artlibrary00inte|title=Art library of the late K.W. Bachstitz (Bachstitz Galleries), The Hague. : Internationaal Antiquariaat (Menno Hertzberger) : Free Download & Streaming : Internet Archive|publisher=archive.org|accessdate=2015-06-11}}</ref>
In 2009 the Dutch government restituted the painting "Roman Capriccio" by [[Pietro Capelli]] from the stock of the SNK to Kurt Walter Bachstitz' grandchildren.<ref name="libmma"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.restitutiecommissie.nl/adviezen/advies_178.html|title=Bachstitz, Restitution Commission of the Netherlands, Az RC 1.78, Consideration No.18|accessdate=2015-06-11}}</ref> The Restitution Committee of the Netherlands denied though a restitution claim concerning a number of other works, among them the works sold to Hitler (Sonderauftrag Linz). In view of most of these works the Committee argued that these sales had not been made under duress because Kurt Walter Bachstitz had been left "undisturbed" in 1940 and 1941.<ref name="libmma"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.restitutiecommissie.nl/adviezen/advies_178.html|title=Bachstitz, Restitution Commission of the Netherlands, Az RC 1.78, Consideration No.5|accessdate=2015-06-11}}</ref> The grandchildren applied in 2013 for the re-opening of the case in this regard.<ref>Act RC 4.138</ref>
In July 2013 the Prussian Heritage Foundation restituted a Tyrolean gothic wall-mounted writing slate (c. 1500) and a large 16th-century Italian bronze mortar.<ref name="preussischer-kulturbesitz">{{cite web|url=http://www.preussischer-kulturbesitz.de/pressemitteilung/news/2013/07/09/berliner-kunstgewerbemuseum-restituiert-zwei-werke-an-die-erben-des-kunsthaendlers-bachstitz.html|title=Berliner Kunstgewerbemuseum restituiert zwei Werke an die Erben des Kunsthändlers Bachstitz - Stiftung Preußischer Kulturbesitz|publisher=preussischer-kulturbesitz.de|accessdate=2015-06-11}}</ref> Kurt Walter Bachstitz' grandchildren are still searching for many works of art that were lost due to National-Socialist persecution<ref name="lostart">{{cite web|url=http://www.lostart.de/Webs/DE/Datenbank/SucheSimpelErgebnis.html?cms_param=SUCHE_ID%3D1970107 |title=Lost Art Internet Database - Einfache Suche |accessdate=2015-06-11 |df= }}{{dead link|date=May 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref>[http://www.lostart.de/Webs/DE/Datenbank/MeldungVerlust.html?cms_param=menu%3Dobjgrp%26INST_ID%3D12215#id83554 48 Search Requests at www.lostart.de, latest view June 11, 2015]</ref>

[[Image:Kyllikki Saari ja siskot.jpg|thumb|250px|Kyllikki Saari (back right) with sisters]]
'''Auli Kyllikki Saari''' (December 6, 1935 – May 17, 1953) was a 17-year-old Finnish girl whose [[murder]] in 1953 is one of the most infamous cases of [[homicide]] ever in [[Finland]]. Her murder in [[Isojoki]] remains unsolved.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tiede.fi/arkisto/artikkeli.php?id%3D146%26vl%3D2000 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-03-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930185628/http://www.tiede.fi/arkisto/artikkeli.php?id=146&vl=2000 |archivedate=2007-09-30 |df= }}</ref>
==Background information== Saari was last seen alive on May 17, 1953.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://imgur.com/gallery/Bnqql|title=Unsolved murders: The Bog Grave|work=Imgur|access-date=2017-09-16|language=en}}</ref> She was [[bicycle|cycling]] home from a [[prayer meeting]] when, it is believed, she was [[assault|attacked]] by an unidentified person. The authorities speculated that the murderer may have had a [[sexual crime|sexual motive]], but no evidence has been produced to support this theory. Although the crime received notable [[mass media|media]] attention, the murderer has never been identified. Saari's remains were found on October 11, 1953 in a [[bog]]. Her bicycle was discovered in a marshy area later that year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www2.hs.fi/english/archive/news.asp?id=20040405IE8 |title=Helsingin Sanomat |publisher=.hs.fi |date= |accessdate=2016-09-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160606012624/http://www2.hs.fi/english/archive/news.asp?id=20040405IE8 |archivedate=2016-06-06 |df= }}</ref> [[Funeral service]]s were held at Isojoki Church on October 25, 1953; an estimated 25,000 people attended.
==Suspects== ===Kauko Kanervo=== Initially, the [[prime suspect]] in the case was [[:fi:Kauko Kanervo|Kauko Kanervo]], a [[parish priest]] who remained under investigation for several years. Kanervo had moved to [[Merikarvia]] three weeks before the murder, and had been reported as having been in the area on the evening of Saari's disappearance. An investigation determined Kanervo had been dean of the party and spent the late night hours in the [[parsonage]]. With all but 20 minutes of his time accounted for, the authorities deduced the priest could not have had enough time to go to Isojoki (60 kilometres away from Merikarvia), as he did not have a drivers license or a car.
===Hans Assmann=== {{Main|Hans Assmann}} Assmann's wife reported that her husband and his driver were near Isojoki at the time of the murder. Assmann also owned a light-brown [[Opel]], the same type of car several [[witness]]es had seen near the murder scene. In 1997, Assmann reportedly confessed his involvement in the crime to a former [[police officer]], Matti Paloaro, and claimed responsibility for the death of Kyllikki Saari. Assmann's story to the officer claimed the death was caused by an [[automobile accident]] when his car, driven by his chauffeur, collided with Saari; to conceal the [[evidence]] of the driver's involvement, the two men staged the case as a murder. According to Paloaro, Assmann said on his deathbed, "One thing however, I can tell you right away ... because it is the oldest one, and in a way it was an accident, that had to be covered up. Otherwise, our trip would have been revealed. Even though my friend was a good driver, the accident was unavoidable. I assume you know what I mean."
Assmann's wife also reported that one of her husband's socks was missing and his shoes were wet when he returned home the evening of the murder. There were also dents in the car. According to Mrs. Assmann, a few days later, Assmann and his driver left again, but this time they had a shovel with them. Later investigators determined that Kyllikki's murderer must have been left-handed, which Assmann was.
Assmann is also alleged to have been the perpetrator of the [[Lake Bodom murders]], which occurred in 1960.
===Vihtori Lehmusviita=== Vihtori Lehmusviita was in a [[mental hospital]] for long periods, and died in 1967, following which his case was set aside. The man police generally held as a [[murderer]] was, at the time, a 38-year-old local inhabitant. He was living within a 1–2 km radius of the site. In the 1940s, Lehmusviita was found guilty of a [[sexual offense]], and had a [[mental illness]]. The police suspected that the murderer got help and cover-up from the 37-year-old brother-in-law of Lehmusviita, who had a [[criminal record|criminal background]]. The suspect's mother and sister gave him an [[alibi]] for the evening of the murder, saying that he was in bed by 19:00 after drinking heavily.
When Lehmusviita was interrogated, he said that Kyllikki was no longer alive, and her body would never be found. Subsequently, he withdrew his statement, claiming that he had been misunderstood. The suspect and his brother-in-law alleged [[accomplice]] were questioned in the autumn of 1953. Shortly after this incident, the brother-in-law moved to [[Central Ostrobothnia]], and then to Sweden. Lehmusviita was questioned twice. He was in a mental hospital for treatment, and when the provincial criminal police came there to question him, the interrogation was made to stop because Lehmusviita's behavior became so strange and confused that his doctor ordered that he could not be questioned in his state.
Both Lehmusviita and his alleged accomplice knew the terrain very well, as they had a common working field located 50 meters from where Kyllikki was found. There was a shovel in the field that was used to dig the [[grave]].
